image.altText: A tall man with a dark-haired beard standing at a protest

items.synopsis: Mark Turner says he only found out Labor would not be renewing his membership after being contacted by a journalist, after the party issued a statement yesterday.

title.children: Member for Blain 'absolutely blindsided' by expulsion from Territory Labor

image.altText: Former prime minister Bob Hawke receives a bark painting from Galarrwuy Yunupingu in 1988.

items.synopsis: The Barunga Festival gets underway, marking 35 years since Indigenous leaders presented the Barunga Statement to former prime minister Bob Hawke. So, what's changed since then?

title.children: It's 35 years since Bob Hawke was presented with the Barunga Statement. What's changed?

image.altText: Donald Trump wears a blue suit and red tie as he speaks into a microphone at a convention.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump says his lawyers have been informed that he has been indicted by the US Department of Justice for mishandling sensitive government documents.

title.children: Trump says he has been indicted over classified documents at Mar-a-Lago

image.altText: Two police cars with flashing lights parked along a closed off section of highway.

items.synopsis: Police say traffic diversions are in place on one of Darwin's busiest roads after a pedestrian was struck and killed by a vehicle this morning.

title.children: Pedestrian dies after being struck by vehicle on Darwin road

image.altText: an offshore jack-up drill rig.

items.synopsis: Supply issues at an offshore gas field force the government-owned electricity provider to rely on emergency gas deals with LNG exporters to keep generators running.

title.children: Top End electricity supply to continue to rely on emergency gas

image.altText: An artistic image showing the back of a police officer and a police car.

items.synopsis: Each year, dozens of people claim to have been injured by police, but only a handful of officers end up facing court for those alleged assaults. In South Australia, police have been accused of charging their alleged victims instead, to stop their allegations being properly investigated.

title.children: Alexander forgot his concession card on a train, a mistake which ended in his arrest and hospitalisation

image.altText: Hugo Byrnes

items.synopsis: Hugo Byrnes is one of a growing number of unlikely digital disciples spreading the word about Christianity online through meme accounts and Bible puns.

title.children: Gen Z gym bros resurrecting Christianity as religion makes godlike gains on social media

image.altText: Two men drink champagne while standing at an office window.

items.synopsis: Sixty-six people earned more than $14 million in the 2020-21 financial year, but new data from the Australian Taxation Office shows they paid zero income tax.

title.children: 66 people earned an average of $14.5 million in 2020-21. None of them paid a cent in tax to the ATO

image.altText: a close-up of a woman's pregnant belly. she has one hand underneath her belly and one on top of it

items.synopsis: The tenants, who are of Kenyan origin, accused the husband-and-wife owners of the building of a campaign against them that included racial discrimination, surveillance, obstructing access and "humiliating and offensive" language.

title.children: 'The child once born, is not authorised': Couple wins racial discrimination case against landlord

image.altText: A lion cub and a black leopard cub hug each other while they sleep.

items.synopsis: The war in Ukraine has not only destroyed infrastructure and claimed human lives, but the natural environment and wildlife have been decimated and could take decades to recover when the war finally ends.

title.children: The full extent of Ukraine's environmental damage isn't known, but what has been discovered already worries experts

image.altText: Ukrainian emergency workers wearing radiation protection suits .

items.synopsis: One of the world's largest nuclear power plants relies on a reservoir attached to the Nova Kakhovka dam. What does that mean now the dam has been destroyed?

title.children: The Zaporizhzhia power plant used water from the destroyed Ukrainian dam. What happens now?

image.altText: Mark Turner, the MLA for the Palmerston seat of Blain, sits in NT Parliament looking concerned.

items.synopsis: Mr Turner says he was made aware of Territory Labor's decision not to renew his membership at the same time as the media.

title.children: NT politician Mark Turner expelled from Labor Party

image.altText: Anthony Albanese smiles next to Mathias Cormann in front of a panel of national flags.

items.synopsis: Research from the OECD shows businesses are the big beneficiaries of inflation so far, but the tables may be starting to turn.

title.children: Cormann-led OECD concludes profits have made a major contribution to inflation

image.altText: Silhouette of two people using laptops in front of the Facebook logo.

items.synopsis: Following the proposal of new anti-discrimination laws in Queensland, claims swirled online that it meant offensive posts on social media could lead to three years of jail. Is that correct?

title.children: CheckMate: Here are the facts on Queensland's proposed anti-discrimination laws

image.altText: A composite image of Jim Chalmers and Philip Lowe.

items.synopsis: The trajectory of wages is just one of the unknowns in the complex situation facing the economy, and thus the government, over the next year, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Everything's going up, including wages. But is that a good thing?

image.altText: A close up of a gloved hand holding a ruby. A woman's face is blurred in the background.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: World's largest ruby sets auction record, and can a robot dog be an art critic? Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A man holds a fish

items.synopsis: There are fears fresh fish prices could "go through the roof" with a ban on gillnet fishing, paving the way for more imported seafood.

title.children: Fish and chip prices to rise with ban on major form of fishing, a fisheries scientist says

image.altText: Three men in forensic gear gather at playground.

items.synopsis: Four children, aged between 22-months and three-years-old, were injured in a knife attack in the French town of Annecy.

title.children: Four toddlers fighting for life after knife attack in France

image.altText: Brett Sutton looks to the side as he stands outdoors, in a shirt and jacket.

items.synopsis: Professor Sutton will join national science agency CSIRO after four years in the role as chief health officer.

title.children: Brett Sutton, who fronted Victoria's COVID response during pandemic, quits chief health officer role

image.altText: Australian currency is seen next to a wages graph

items.synopsis: CBA economists slash forecasts, put odds of a recession this year at 50:50. The ASX is on the rise. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: 50 per cent chance of a recession says CBA, ASX follows Wall St tech rally

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The portion of Australians working more than one job has increased to a new record high at the start of the year. The Bureau of Statistics says 947,000 people held multiple jobs in the March quarter. That's 19,000 more than in the final three months of 2022 — and 173,000 more than pre-Covid. That means around one-in-15 people are now holding down more than one job, the highest rate since records began in the 1990s. The biggest increases were in the health care and social assistance industry and in accommodation and food services. Women and young people are more likely to have at least two jobs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New record for Australians working multiple jobs

children.content: The portion of Australians working more than one job has increased to a new record high at the start of the year.
The Bureau of Statistics says 947,000 people held multiple jobs in the March quarter.
That's 19,000 more than in the final three months of 2022 — and 173,000 more than pre-Covid.
That means around one-in-15 people are now holding down more than one job, the highest rate since records began in the 1990s.
The biggest increases were in the health care and social assistance industry and in accommodation and food services.
Women and young people are more likely to have at least two jobs.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An overall gloomy update to their economic forecasts from CBA's economics team. Odds of a recession in 2023 at 50%; Forecasts based on one more RBA cash rate rise to 4.35%, but risk of two more to 4.6%; Unemployment rate to end 2023 at 4.4% and to be 4.7% by mid-2024. But it's not all bad: The annual rate of inflation to decline to 3.8% by late 2023 (CBA forecast is for underlying inflation to be 3.6%/yr in Q4 23); CBA expects 1.25 percentage points of rate cuts in 2024. CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird expects consumers to drive the downturn, with household consumption falling per capita, and possibly outright, this year. While the Reserve Bank has focused on the stock of savings Australians accumulated during the pandemic, Mr Aird says they are concentrated amongst people who don't need to spend them, and probably won't as the economy tanks. "A large stock of savings were accrued during the pandemic. But the savings were not distributed evenly. The bulk of the savings amassed during the pandemic sit within the older cohort of society. "We do not expect this demographic to draw down on their savings swiftly. Rather they are likely to spend these savings in a protracted way over many years. The upshot is that we do not anticipate a speedy injection of the accrued savings back into the economy. "Households as a collective tend to draw down on savings when they are feeling positive about the economic outlook. That is not the case right now." And for households with mortgages — especially those with large, recent mortgages, like the 35-44-year-olds who bought a home during the pandemic and saw their savings decline — things will be tougher than they have ever been before. But, while CBA expects 2023 to be something of an annus horribilis for the Australian economy, Mr Aird is more upbeat about our prospects when we get through to the other side in 2024. "Readers may feel like there is a pessimistic tone to this note. That is understandable. Economists don't take pleasure in downgrading the outlook for economic growth and upwardly revising their forecasts for unemployment. But there is light at the end of the tunnel. "Once the proverbial 'inflation dragon' is slayed monetary policy will be able to move away from a deeply restrictive setting to a more neutral one. Rate relief will arrive to the household sector in the future and we expect that to happen in early 2024. "As interest rates are cut it will free up cash for those borrowers that have a mortgage. And the demand for credit will begin to lift. As this happens economic momentum will start to pick up and the upward trend in the unemployment rate will wane. Consumer sentiment and spending will lift. "Our expectation is that the unemployment rate will peak at 4.7% in mid 2024 before grinding back down to 4.5% in late 2024 ." So, batten down the hatches, try and make it through this year, and hopefully that light at the end of the tunnel for 2024 isn't an oncoming train. Gareth Aird has spoken to Rachel Pupazzoni about his latest forecasts. Keep an eye out for the interview on Close of Business and the ABC News YouTube channel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Recession now a 50/50 chance says CBA, but there's 'light at the end of the tunnel'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some mortgage borrowers are caught in something of a Catch-22 of the banking regulator's making. Because APRA removed a 7% floor on its mortgage serviceability test, many borrowers were offered loans during the pandemic period based on whether they could afford repayments if their mortgage rate rose to 5%, in some cases perhaps even less than that. A typical variable mortgage rate is now closer to 6% after the RBA's latest rate hike, so that leaves these borrowers paying more than the maximum they were tested to be able to afford. I wrote about the problems this was likely to create late last year, before the RBA added a further percentage point to the cash rate so far in 2023. One way to try and close that gap is by refinancing to one of the cheaper rates in the market. But to do that, you have to meet the serviceability test again. But this time, instead of being tested on whether you can afford rates around 5%, you'll be tested on whether you can still pay your mortgage at 9% interest rates. Research from RateCity has found a family of four, where one parent works full-time and the other part-time at half the wage, on a combined annual income of $143,221 before tax, will have seen their maximum borrowing capacity drop by $247,700 as a result of the 12 RBA hikes and the current serviceability test. That leaves many people in mortgage prison, stuck on an uncompetitive rate but unable to switch lenders to a better deal. Today APRA has written to the banks, credit unions and building societies that it regulates warning them not to be too generous with serviceability test exemptions that could help some borrowers get out of mortgage prison. "APRA requires banks to have prudent policies and processes for dealing with exceptions to policy. "Large volumes of exceptions can create risks by weakening banks' risk profiles and increasing the vulnerability of their loan books to future shocks. "Historically, serviceability policy exceptions have accounted for a small share of banks' total housing lending, at between 2 and 3 per cent. "It is important that exceptions are used in a prudent and limited manner, so as not to undermine the intent of the core policy. "In using exceptions, APRA expects banks to make a prudent assessment of repayment capacity so that there is a good outcome for borrowers and the financial system." Given that estimates from some of the major banks and leading bank analysts put between 15-25% of borrowers in this situation, it seems most will remain stuck in mortgage prison for quite a while yet.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: APRA pulls in one potential lifeline for struggling borrowers

featuredLink.title: Banks face 'mortgage prisoners' and escapees as the reality of soaring rates bites

children.content: Some mortgage borrowers are caught in something of a Catch-22 of the banking regulator's making.
Because APRA removed a 7% floor on its
mortgage serviceability test
, many borrowers were offered loans during the pandemic period based on whether they could afford repayments if their mortgage rate rose to 5%, in some cases perhaps even less than that.
A typical variable mortgage rate is now closer to 6% after the RBA's latest rate hike, so that leaves these borrowers paying more than the maximum they were tested to be able to afford.
I wrote about the problems this was likely to create late last year
, before the RBA added a further percentage point to the cash rate so far in 2023.
One way to try and close that gap is by refinancing to one of the cheaper rates in the market.
But to do that, you have to meet the serviceability test again. But this time, instead of being tested on whether you can afford rates around 5%, you'll be
tested on whether you can still pay your mortgage at 9% interest rates
Research from RateCity
has found a family of four, where one parent works full-time and the other part-time at half the wage, on a combined annual income of $143,221 before tax, will have seen their
maximum borrowing capacity drop by $247,700
as a result of the 12 RBA hikes and the current serviceability test.
That leaves many people in
mortgage prison
, stuck on an uncompetitive rate but unable to switch lenders to a better deal.
Today
APRA has written to the banks, credit unions and building societies that it regulates
warning them not to be too generous with serviceability test exemptions
that could help some borrowers get out of mortgage prison.
"APRA requires banks to have prudent policies and processes for dealing with exceptions to policy.
"Large volumes of exceptions can create risks by weakening banks' risk profiles and increasing the vulnerability of their loan books to future shocks.
"Historically, serviceability policy exceptions have accounted for a small share of banks' total housing lending, at between 2 and 3 per cent.
"It is important that exceptions are used in a prudent and limited manner, so as not to undermine the intent of the core policy.
"In using exceptions, APRA expects banks to make a prudent assessment of repayment capacity so that there is a good outcome for borrowers and the financial system."
Given that estimates from some of the major banks and leading bank analysts put between
15-25% of borrowers
in this situation, it seems most will remain stuck in mortgage prison for quite a while yet.

image.altText: Scott Boland smiles as teammates surround him

items.synopsis: Scott Boland was always going to do well in English conditions with a Duke ball, but it was still impressive to see him do it as Australia stayed in control of the ICC World Test Championship final against India at The Oval.

title.children: Five things we learnt at the WTC Final: Brilliant Boland backs up hype

image.altText: A young man on a road looks down at his watch. He is wearing workout gear. One knee is on the ground.

items.synopsis: Australians would be warned within minutes if they were falling sick under an ambitious new plan from scientists, who hope artificial intelligence will be the key to stopping the next pandemic or slowing the spread of weaponised diseases.

title.children: How wearable technology could become the first line of defence against biological warfare

image.altText: People wait for fireworks at Sydney Harbour Bridge

items.synopsis: North Sydney Council's ballooning legal bill comes as a new report from the NSW Productivity Commission finds the city's most affluent suburbs must become higher and denser to arrest the housing crisis.

title.children: Sydney council spends millions blocking developments, as mayor at risk of losing her view

image.altText: Apollo 8's Iconic Earthrise

items.synopsis: China has made giant leaps in space exploration and technology over the past year – and NASA is worried.

title.children: NASA has declared the US is in a new space race with China. How close is it?

image.altText: A young Aboriginal man standing on an outback runway in front of a small aircraft and looking serious.

items.synopsis: In some of Australia's most remote communities, where many don't speak English as a first language, an Indigenous community broadcaster is reaching out to learn residents' views about the Indigenous Voice to Parliament ahead of the referendum.

title.children: Damien has travelled Australia talking to communities about the Voice. Here's what he found

image.altText: A man with long, blonde, curly hair, poses and smiles at a camera, wearing a pattern shirt, standing in front of a window.

items.synopsis: Scott White was arrested in 2020 over Scott Johnson's death, decades after the then-27-year-old's body was found at the base of cliffs in Manly near a gay beat.

title.children: 'Our family has got some peace': Sydney cliff killer jailed decades after death of US mathematician

image.altText: Cameron Green celebrates

items.synopsis: Australia has a lead of 318 runs after day two of the World Test Championship Final saw India reduced to 5-151, after Steve Smith's century helped Australia to 469 all out in their first innings.

title.children: Australia in control against India after another dominant performance

image.altText: A young girl sits in the centre of the jaws of a large shark with her sister in a wheelchair behind her

items.synopsis: The McWaters have two daughters with childhood dementia as a result of Batten Disease. They say they are luckier than some as they get to see their children grow up, but they want to see a better understanding of the disease and respite options.

title.children: Childhood dementia will cut these sisters' lives short. Their parents want better respite services — not sympathy

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: Mr Trump's lawyers say the jury's $2.98 million award for the sexual abuse portion of the verdict was "excessive" because the jury had found that Ms Carroll was not raped, and that the conduct she alleged did not cause any diagnosed mental injury.

title.children: Trump asks for new trial in E Jean Carroll sex abuse case

image.altText: A photo of the Darwin city skyline showing buildings in the CBD on a sunny dry season day.

items.synopsis: The vice-chancellor of the NT's biggest university calls for people to open up spare bedrooms to students, as calls grow for vacant office space to potentially be used as a temporary solution.

title.children: Could vacant offices help solve Darwin's tight student accommodation market?

image.altText: A man with a moustache and goatee and wearing a cap standing in front of a building and smiling.

items.synopsis: A 42-year-old man is charged with a string of charges, including attempting to pervert the course of justice, after Tony Rowe's remains were found south of Darwin last month.

title.children: Third person charged over disappearance and death of Darwin man Tony Rowe

image.altText: Aryna Sabalenka and Alexander Lukashenko.

items.synopsis: Aryna Sabalenka is "not an expert in politics" and never has that been more apparent than when she denounced a war and an autocratic strongman with a history of revenge.

title.children: Europe's last dictator celebrated this young tennis star. Then Aryna Sabalenka publicly disowned him

image.altText: A Navy officer in camo fatigues uses binoculars to look from the side of his ship towards another boat across choppy grey water

items.synopsis: China says all of the South China Sea belongs to it and presses its claims with a huge deployment of coast guard and fishing boats as far as 1,500km off its coastline, while Indonesia says the planned exercise is about  strengthening "ASEAN centrality".

title.children: ASEAN to hold first joint military exercise off Indonesia as South China Sea tensions simmer

image.altText: A young woman with red lipstick smiles while hugging her grandmother

items.synopsis: Around one in three families has multiple generations living under the same roof. Cost of living could see that figure increase.

title.children: Young people are moving back in with their families — and it's not just them benefiting

image.altText: A view from above of water surrounding houses.

items.synopsis: Nine people are injured by shelling and Ukraine says the average level of flooding in the Kherson region is 5.61 metres as authorities work to evacuate more people after the collapse of the Nova Kakhovka dam.

title.children: Russia shells Ukraine's Kherson as residents flee flood waters from destroyed dam
